DOCNAME: G. and A. v. FINLAND and SWEDEN
TEXT: The first applicant is a NORP and the second applicant a NORP national . They were born in DATE and DATE respectively and are currently living in GPE , GPE .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the applicants , may be summarised as follows .

The applicants and their son PERSON ( born in DATE ) first lived in GPE until DATE , when they moved to his grandmother in GPE ) after a public care order had been issued in GPE . In both countries ORG underwent intelligence and other tests on account of certain behavioural problems ( indications of slight retardation and autism , increasing isolation and aggression ) . The NORP authorities considered his symptoms to be of a psychological nature . The applicants considered them neurological but this contention could not be supported by any of the expert findings . Nonetheless , the applicants did not accept that ORG be admitted for further examinations at a child psychiatric clinic .

In DATE the applicant father was detained for DATE with a view to assessing whether he was in need of compulsory mental care on account of possible paranoia . On DATE , after the municipality had excluded ORG from his regular school class due to his behavioural disturbances , the family returned to GPE .

On DATE ORG ( sosiaalilautakunta , socialnämnden ) of PERSON placed NORP in public care under LAW ( lastensuojelulaki , barnskyddslag CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) . According to the applicants , they were not heard prior to the making of the order . Their appeal was dismissed by ORG ( lääninoikeus , länsrätten ) of ORG . On DATE ORG ( korkein hallinto - oikeus , högsta förvaltningsdomstolen ) dismissed their further appeal . They had contended , inter alia , that the reports given by the authorities had contained incorrect information and that ORG ’s referral to the child psychiatric clinic , which had been signed by the doctor of the health care centre , had not been made available to them . Having considered the evidence adduced , the court found no indication that the information given by the authorities had been incorrect . The court concluded , in light of the evidence adduced , that the referral report had not been at the disposal of ORG either .

In DATE , when consulting the case - file at ORG , the applicants allegedly discovered a number of false and misleading documents which had not been communicated to them in the proceedings concerning the initial care order . Their request to have the proceedings re - opened on this ground was dismissed by ORG on DATE . The court found no procedural error which could have had a significant effect on its earlier decision .

On DATE NORP police fetched NORP and transferred him to the NORP authorities pursuant to a NORP treaty on the enforcement of care orders . His public care was initially implemented in a clinic for severely physically and mentally retarded children at PERSON , where he underwent various intelligence and other ability tests . The conditions were allegedly harsh .

On DATE ORG maintained ORG public care , dismissing the ORG request to the contrary . Their appeal was dismissed on DATE after an oral hearing before ORG . Meanwhile , in DATE I. had been admitted to a child psychiatric clinic for further examinations . In DATE he was placed in a foster family at GPE , where the applicants allegedly had difficulties in gaining access to him . On DATE ORG declined to examine their appeal in so far as concerning ORG ’s placement at GPE , that having been a temporary placement against which no appeal avenue had been open . The court likewise declined to examine their appeal against the access restriction as under domestic law this had been finally determined by ORG . The court dismissed the other aspects of their appeal .

Meanwhile , on DATE ORG decided to place NORP in a children ’s home in GPE . In DATE he was placed in another foster family in GPE in order to attend another school . ORG granted the ORG request to fly ORG to the GPE to be examined by specialists . The applicants’ appeals in the other respects were dismissed by ORG on DATE . On DATE ORG dismissed their further appeals concerning ORG ’s transfer to the children ’s home and declined to examine the other aspects .

For financial reasons , the applicants had to postpone their trip with I. to the GPE until DATE . On DATE , however , ORG withdrew its permission for ORG to go on the trip after experts had considered that a trip at that moment would not be in his best interests . On DATE the ORG restricted the meetings between ORG and the applicants to one per month and dismissed their new request to take NORP on a trip to the GPE . Their appeal was dismissed on DATE . On DATE ORG declined to examine their further appeal , as no right to a further appeal existed .

A restriction on visits has allegedly been in force throughout ORG ’s public care , and was prolonged by ORG , most recently , in DATE . Currently CARDINAL DATE visit is allowed in the children ’s home . In DATE ORG again refused the applicants permission to take NORP on a trip to the GPE .
The ORG appeal against the recent access restriction and the refusal to allow NORP to travel to the GPE was dismissed by ORG ( hallinto - oikeus , förvaltningsdomstolen ) on DATE .
According to the Government , the facts of the case are as follows .
By a letter of CARDINAL DATE , ORG of Luopionen had informed the applicants that , on DATE , it was going to consider a proposal to place NORP in public care . ORG had recalled , inter alia :

“ The problems relating to the growth and development of your son [ ... ] have been discussed at several meetings which you have also attended . However , because you have not consented to the examinations and rehabilitation needed for the purpose of helping your son , public care [ has been ] found appropriate . ”

In the same letter the ORG had invited the applicants to comment on the proposed care order , either orally in the social welfare office on DATE or in writing by DATE . Furthermore , they had been told that they would be able to consult the ORG ’s case - file during their possible visit on DATE . Receipt of the letter had been acknowledged by the applicants on DATE in GPE , where they had lived since DATE .

The applicants had not taken any contact with ORG which had issued the proposed care order and referred the matter for approval by ORG . After the applicants had appealed the court had invited them to comment on ORG rejoinder with annexes ( i.e. a decision of ORG ( kammarrätten ) of GPE of DATE and a summary of the measures taken by the NORP authorities from DATE onwards ) . The applicants had submitted their comments on DATE and in subsequent letters .

After the applicants had appealed against ORG decision of CARDINAL DATE ORG had afforded them an opportunity to comment in writing on ORG rejoinder . ORG had noted , inter alia , that its decision had been based on several reports and opinions , beginning with the documents relating to the public care order issued in GPE in DATE . The court ’s letter had been received by the applicants on DATE and the second applicant had submitted written comments .

In their comments in reply to the factual information provided by the Government the applicants contend that CARDINAL specific reports considered by ORG on DATE ( and listed in its decision ) had not been made available to them until DATE , i.e. after the initial care proceedings had ended . The further report of the NORP social welfare authorities dated DATE had been made available to them only in the Convention proceedings . In that document the official had recounted the NORP social authorities’ suspicion in DATE that ORG had been sexually abused in the family , which the applicants deny .
The relevant legislation is outlined in the ORG ’s judgment in PERSON and GPE ( [ ORG ] , no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , § § CARDINAL , ECHR DATE ) .
